Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2011 05:17AM lilylady wrote: Dear Ladies,   . I had my BMX with no-recon  or nodes on Monday. Stayed overnight but really could have went on home. The next day we stopped for Chinese at my favorite place and  a short trip to Lowes also. Got home and took a nap them made myself some scrambled eggs for dinner. Stayed up and watched a little TV then went to bed with an Ambien.   I have needed no pain pills so far. I am wearing a ON-Q pain ball til friday and i thimk that is why I am feeling so good. It hangs from my waist with a belt. It is about half the size of a bowling ball. It has 2 tiny tubes threaded up thru the incisions. I will pull them when I remove my dressings on Friday.She wrote a scip for Vicodin but I haven't needed 1 yet. The drains are annoying but I have a wardrobe of short sleeved hoodies-we cut a hole in the back of the pocket and fish the drains in from the back. That way they aren't swaying all over the place. I bought the wedge pillow from Bed Bath  and Beyond but I think I will return it. It was $29 plus an aditional $10 for an extra cover. I slept fine in my own bed with lots of extra pillows to prop me and my arms up.Not having re-con probably made my case lots easier. I will remove the dressing and bra on friday and I can shower on Saturday. YAY. The whole thing was so much easier than I had thought. The last thing I can remember is the surgeon putting the sign of the cross on my foehead and then kissing the same spot and then I was out!! BS called last night to say all margins were clear. She found extensive scar tissue on my my chest wall but it was just that-scar tissue. My tumor was attached there to start with. I will not see her until the drains are ready to come out.   The one thing I wish is that the rest of you up for this week have a good experience also. I plan on being up and active as possible today-probably with some power naps worked in.

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2012 07:29AM lilylady wrote: Abby-I am a stage IV Her 2 and while it is very aggressive they have some understanding how our cancer works so we are getting lots of research money. Today I started with a Her 2 drug that was just approved June 6. It achieved major results in trials. There is also a drug that will be up for approval in Dec. So being Her2 isn't all that bad.   I did chemo before surgery last year. My original tumor was 9cm and by surgery time all my mets had become Micro-mets.   You will get your final diagnosis and belive me while it is overwhelming like everybody elsesays you can do this. They tell you prepare to give up 1 year of your life and while that was true it flew by. You will have all the friends and support you ned on this site.   I encourage you to join a chemo thread of people starting theirs the same time as you. These will be the ladies you get closest to-they will be going thru the same stuff at the same time. you will learn so many things from them

I realize this is minor compared to what some of you have been thru but I already feel like a freak.One side you will never be able to see the scar but the other side will show in any kind of summer top.

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2011 06:21AM lilylady wrote: Blondelawyer-as far as sleeping I bought the wedge pillow from Bed Bath and Beyond ($29) and it has been a godsend. I also use a smaller flatter pillow on top of it.  It comes with a cover and you can buy additional covers for $10. I also have a pillow on either side of my body for my arms to lay on. When I go to bed or get up I just try to stiffen my back and roll my legs in or out first then lay back or raise up. Putting your arms down to push yourself up is  a no-no. I also started taking Ambien again-I haven't used it in months but I probably wouldn't have been able to sleep with out it. But again-I had no nodes or recon-from what I have read the TEs make a huge difference in mobility.  I have not needed much help and I have went out every day since my surgery. I use a fanny pack for my drains (which come out tomorrow YAY). I started driving at Day 5. I have worked in the garden, walked, done some cooking and dishwashing but have stayed strictly away from anything over 5 lbs. I really stocked the house up before surgery both with groceries, books and movies, pet food and suppplies.     I might also suggest putting some favorite snacks in your purse for the hospital. They starved me on my overnight stay. The only thing they offered was saltines and diet vanilla pudding. I would have killed for some Cheddar Goldfish and a little piece of chocolate. Their food was horrible!!    Thinking about all our Monday girls and hoping for the very best results.

I had terrible muscle cramping which they finally found a drug that made it bearable. I also reduced the dose to 70%-that helped also. I was on 3 weeks and off one.  I did Neupagen after every treatment. It boosts your blood counts-Navelbine is very hard on them. You really should see a pallative doc if her onc is that unhelpful and she really needs to look into getting someone who wants to help. Cancer is bad enough without putting up with a jerk like him. Palliative care is somewhat new and there are actual palliative docs with certification-my practice actually has 2.   I take care of my parents full time while doing chemo and the rest of the cancer stuff-not so easy and I don't have the small kids to deal with so I feel for you.

Posts.Content: lilylady wrote: I went for me PET this morning-and was surprised that I got a nice sized box of candy for being such an outstanding patient (wonder if they ever heard that cancer feeds on sugar? Isn't that why you go carb and sugar free the day before a scan?). Got a vein on the first try, laid absolutely still for 20 minutes and gave vacation advice to the tech-glad I was outstanding for at least part of the day. It sure went downhill from there.   I was surprised to get a call from my onc in the early afternoon with my results. Never a good sign when they call you that quick is it?  All mets icreased in size and activity and a met found in the liver-which had been cancer free since last August. Stopping Xeloda/Tykerb and moving on to the new Her2 drug Perjeta. I searched and didn;t see anyone else posting about taking it. Bad part is it pairs with Taxotere so my darling short hair-do which took 16 months to bcome darling is going to fall out again. Also back on herceptin which failed me last January.  He wants me to stop working immediately but I am going to try it and see. Last year I took Taxol 5 times before it made me sick-but I wasn't working in a factory where it is 110 degrees almost daily now. If insurance approves I will get my first dose next Tuesday-I have not missed the chemo room-that's for sure. Not sure if it is 6 tx or how exactly it is done but I will find out soon.  So I am off to start a weekend binge of every kind of food I can think of before my tastebuds go. Starting with fresh corn on the cob, tomatoes, cucumbers and yellow cupcakes with chocolate frosting. I am not telling anyone else this weekend. Next week will be soon enough. Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2012 11:07PM lilylady wrote: It is still so strange to me how regional various treatment regimens are-specifically the mx for a  Stage IV, In my case and for my doctor it isn;t even a consideration-mx is part of the tx protocol. I kow what they say about survival stats ect are not any different wether you have the mx or not but for me that sucker was like the mothership from where all evil flowed. Mine was huge and not really in the breast-it was behind the breast embedded in the chest wall. I did neo-chemo and it did really shrink down but I was never so happy as when we got that thing off of me. I could have said no to it-I did say no to any axillary nodes-but my doc and I are on the same page as far as being aggressive.  It did creep me out because all I could envision was a little stream of Pac-Man like things steadily marching forth and further invading my body. Like SuperFoob said any way to get rid of any of the cancer is always going to be my first choice.  And BCO has been the best thing I have ever participated in. The depth of knowledge and wisdom among this group astounds me daily. I thought I did a good job learning about my disease but it doesn;t begin to touch what sime of you can do. I am thankful for  and appreciate it more than I can say.   And if we are rare doesn;t that also make us special?

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2014 08:38AM lilylady wrote: I just got my second Ixempra yesterday. Must not be widely used because there sure isn't much posted about it. I am doing it by itself-I had done Xeloda 3 years ago (hated it/horrible hand-foot problem). It is too soon for me to say how this drug is going to be for me. When I got my first dose 3 weeks ago I also found out I had brain mets the same day and I wasn't sure wether I laid on the couch for days because of the chemo or the shock of the brain tumors. I had Gamma Knife to treat 8 tumors last week.  I got terrible acid reflux especially when I laid down-over the counter stuff worked but at 3 times the normal dose. He has ordered me some Protonix (sp?) and it seems to be working. And taste buds were blown for about 10 days. So not too bad overall. I always say I want 3 treatments under my belt before I say what happens consistently.   I have been on weekly chemo for almost  2 years so just going every 3 weeks is so nice. I thought I was going to be one of the lucky 3 % that doesn't lose their hair but at Day 20 it fell out by the handfuls. Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2011 10:16AM lilylady wrote:   One of the first things someone told me when I was diagnosed was "Prepare to give up the next year of your life to cancer". I am sorry to say that it is pretty much true. I hope to wrap up by the end of the year and I started in late Feb.   As far as your oncology visit tomorrow-there are a couple of threads on here on what questions to ask. Don;t worry if you don't understand it all but take good notes-or have your friend take the notes-and ask for spellings-it makes the research easier.   I did my chemo first-and it made me nuts that they were leaving cancer in me-I wanted that sucker out right away-but I am so glad that's how it worked out. Most of the chemo regimes are pretty definite for whatever type of cancer you have. When I was dxed I didn;t even know there were different kinds of breast cancer! Anyway, since most chemo is specific for your cancer there aren't a lot of decisions to be made on that front. the surgery however involves making lots of decisions. There are so many kinds of reconstructions and you will want to learn about all of those before you decide. When you do the chemo first you have the time to do research and talk to people about all your options. They call chemo before surgery neo-adjuvant. It was advocated for me because my tumor was large and attached to the chest wall.   I have come a long way since February in both knowledge and prognosis. The fact that you have found this web sitemakes you way ahead of the game. Anyone on here will tell you they have learned more on here than they ever dlo at their docs office!    You will be fine-take deep breaths and realize this is a process-and there is always someone out here that will listen or help.

Have not used any pain pills. I am wearing an ON=Qpain ball til Friday so it is taking care of it for me I guess. Had a power nap when I got hime and fixed eggs for my supper, watche TV th en slept in my own bed with an army of pillows. Was over before I knew it.Pretty much can move my arms anywhere-some spots hurt so I am being careful there. No-recon makes it much simpler I think. I won't see the BS again til the drains are ready to come out. I get to remove my dressing on Friday and the pain ball catheters nd I can shower on Saturday.   Was very disappointed with the Breast Center though. I have had no contact with any cancer society, group therapy thing ect. She came in with a list of  all these programs they have available-many of which would have been handy thru the past 6 months. She also brought a very expensive post-op bra. My band size is a 40 so when she pulled this thing out of the box it looked like they had stuffed it to a DD. I told her I was not having re-con and no way would I ever try to wear a bra stuffed with quilt batting that stuck out that far. When she removed the batting the bra cups were huge. No way to wear it without stuffing it hat full-otherwise it would just have a bunch of fabric hangin down. She said the cup size was appropriate for the band size. I was a solid B before with a 40" band and it was always a struggle to find well fitting bras but this just felt like a slap. I made my decision not to reconstruct and it felt like they thought no one would consider going anywhere without a bra stuffed with something fake. turned me off the whole thing altogether. Posts.Content: May 1, 2011 10:47PM lilylady wrote: kks-late on a Sunday night there aren't many people posting but I will help all I can. There are lots of exisitng threads for beginners. What to ask on your dr visit, how to read your test results, explanations of the different types of breast cancer, ect. You can pick up tons of info from them, just look thru the forum index and pick a topic and then it lists all the threads within it. Great idea to get all your reports and ask for CDs of any scans or tests. Never too early to start a binder.  Most people start with a surgeon. You might be able to Google the ones they suggested to see if you like what you read. What hospitals they work out of, patient reviews, what kind of practice they do-like cancerous breast only or other types of breast things. Don't be surprised if it takes a couple of weeks to get an appointment-belive me I was shocked when I found out the world didn't stop when I got BC. I was told by one receptionist-"It's not like it's going to get way worse in 2 weeks!" It wasn't as if she wasn't right but it WAS pretty insensitive. I also don't think your gyno sending you for an ultrasound qualifies them as the first opinion. The BS (breast surgeon) does their thing but you will also see an oncologist. I have seen 2 surgeons and 2 oncologists. I went to the first surgeon who would get me in to get a biopsy but I didn't like her from the get-go. I took my biospy reports and then went somewhere else. Seeing the surgeon is the way to start though. Mine then scheduled me for other tests before I saw the oncologist. In my case I am getting chemo frst and surgery later. My PCP gets copied on reports from both the surgeon and the Onc so I don't call her about anything. You will have enough visits to keep you busy without adding that. Or maybe you have a good relationship with yours and want them to hear it from you. I am never sick so she is really a stranger to me. A great book for overall knowledge of breast cancer is Susan Loves Breast Book. All the big bookstores sell it. BC has a whole language and she covers everything from anatomy to survival. When you get past the first rush of testing and office visits there are more great book referrals on here too. I was diagnosed on Feb 18 and here is the biggest piece of advice I can give you-TRY NOT TO PANIC. It seems so overwhelming in the beginning but every part of this crap is do-able if you break it down into little pieces. Crying is part of it-everyone has done it. And that is the beauty of this entire web site.There isn't one thing in your cancer experience that you will have to do by yourself-there is always someone on this site that can empathize or sympathize because they have already been there. I hoped this helped a little. Maybe a more experienced member will come along and steer you better. I wish you luck and will add you to my prayers tonight.
